review_title: Burlingame location only*** Admin mismanagement. Nurses are treated poorly.
job_title: Staff Nurse II in Burlingame, CA
pros: Benefits are great. Labs are 100% covered within Sutter system.
cons: Burlingame location *** Very high turnover rate. Administration's main focus is bottom line despite huge number of CA labor law infractions. Bedside nurses are stretched the thinnest, few breaks if you're lucky. High turnover rate for managers too. Unable to make the slightest change in the schedule, very rigid and inflexible about the schedule and PTO. Administration drives nurses away. Nurses' union contract hasn't been signed in 2 years which means no pay increases while inflation and housing costs are through the roof. Stress from patient care is 5 out of 10. Stress from administration mismanagement is 10 out of 10. Do not recommend!

pros: The hospital is a beautiful building, has free parking, and it is easily accessible to the highway. The front line clinical staff are very good.
cons: This hospital has several layers of management, which may appear to the outsider that they have the help to get things done, but the reality is quite opposite. Bureaucracy is king here and no one wants to (or feels empowered to) make a decision. If you are bold enough to make a decision for the department, you disrupt the existing micro-managed system. Disruptions to their system causes people to have emotional meltdowns, who then later try to snipe you behind your back to your 1 up rather than having a direct conversation with their colleague. When asking others about simple regulatory expectations, facility personnel have a myriad of excuses or some non-evidence based rationale to explain their poor decision making or overall lack of clinical experience. It seems that many managers/directors at this facility have a complete lack of emotional intelligence and behave like small children despite your efforts of being cordial and professional. The physicians here are overly engaged and involve themselves in the day to day operations while making little effort to hold their peers accountable. For example, frontline nursing and ancillary staff are ostracized for wearing hospital-owned scrubs outside the building, regardless of the duration, but physicians are allowed to come and go wearing hospital issued scrubs. Physicians are also allowed to violate hospital policies as long as they secure a waiver from medical staff office. The culture here is volatile, energy draining, and TOXIC. The cons outweigh the pros at this campus. If you need constant micro-managing to do your job, even when you know more than your boss, this is the place for you.

review_title: The most toxic, and unethical place ever
pros: free parking, health insurance if the position is has benefits
cons:
Sadly, most departments at this hospital have horrible work environments. Managers are allowed to harass, use retaliation, and so on. HR doesn't do anything, they don't bother investigating employees issues. If they need to lie to protect them; they will with no shame. Service employees become an easy target, senior leadership allows for abuse of power, and majority of younger men are given a higher hourly pay. 
The work environment at Mills Peninsula is very unprofessional, and dishonorable place. Not only do they discriminate second language speakers, they are bias towards senior employees. 

NOTE:
Most of the time the PATIENTS rooms don't get disinfected nor cleaned.

pros: MPHS/PAMF tends to pay a little higher than other groups in the area -- it can afford to pay more because of the reasons listed below.
cons: MPHS/PAMF is a terrible place to work, mainly because of unethical practices from the leadership.  The Urgent Care Clinic, for example, is staffed by very incompetent doctor leaders who have absolutely no empathy for patients or the doctors they are managing.  I work as a doctor there, and day after day, I see the doctors who are considered our leaders purposefully overcharge patients for excessive tests (e.g. pregnancy testing in 7 year old girls) so that they can get paid more for billing more.  In fact, all of us doctors were put in trainings to teach us how to bill the patient more.  We are even in meetings where some of the top paid doctors discuss how to use tax evasion to our benefit.  Several doctors, the good ones, have all quit, so this place is very desperate in hiring.  Some of the other departments may have better leaders, but overall, MPHS/PAMF is under a productivity model, where the doctors are under pressure to bill more at the patient's expense so that they can get paid more proportionally themselves.  Additionally, there is a huge gender bias.  If you start unveiling the dirt, the male doctors are praised for unethical practices described above and thus are paid more.  When female doctors speak up, they are usually labeled as "difficult" or "not a team player."  It is very sad to me that a healthcare establishment can be so greedy, unfair, and unethical.

review_title: Big Brother, MPH, tells you when, how far, and how long you HAVE to do it without consideration of what Happened to you.
pros: If you are a nurse, at least you can contribute your skills and knowledge. However, computer charting and inane ever changing polices knock the backbone out of what one is called to do in giving ample care to the patient. Here, it's about the money. For who? The hospital.
cons: Little care, thought, or consideration of a Professional's needs. Work related injuries are shunned as being "much to do about nothing."  Policies forever change without input from employees. Those that implement these policies are most often inexperienced and focused on only their "expertise" while disregarding the flow of the entire system or purpose.

review_title: Mills-Peninsula anesthesia group (ACAMG) is not a good career move
pros:
Location near San Francisco.
Excellent ancillary services and decent quality of surgeons
cons:
The group is run like a totalitarian regime by four or five people. The is no transparency. It is not democratic. The CEO is appointed for life regardless of his incompetence. The group has put itself up for sale and no one wants to buy it.
Toxic environment with very many unhappy anesthesiologists.
